text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: GUIDANCE NOTE SERIES
label: HH1

text: DATA RESPONSIBILITY IN HUMANITARIAN ACTION
label: HH1

text: RESPONSIBLE APPROACHES TO DATA SHARING
label: HH1

text: KEY TAKEAWAYS:
label: HH1

text: •	 Open sharing of timely and accurate data is essential to effective and efficient humanitarian
label: BODY

text: response. How humanitarian organizations approach data sharing directly relates to trust and
label: BODY

text: cooperation in the sector.
label: BODY

text: •	 As the humanitarian data ecosystem grows, the opportunities and risks of sharing data become
label: BODY

text: clearer, prompting organizations to explore more limited approaches to data sharing.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian organizations widely recognize the sensitivity of personal data: its exposure has a
label: BODY

text: high likelihood of causing harm. The majority of non-personal data is safe to share openly, but
label: BODY

text: non-personal data can also be sensitive and should be handled with caution.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian organizations should take into account four factors when deciding whether to
label: BODY

text: share non-personal data: (i) utility; (ii) sensitivity; (iii) human and technical capacity; and (iv)
label: BODY

text: governance.
label: BODY

text: •	 Humanitarian organizations should identify and compare all available approaches for data
label: BODY

text: sharing, considering the most open approach first and working down to more limited approaches
label: BODY

text: as necessary.
label: BODY

text: INTRODUCTION
label: HH1

text: The use and exchange of data have become core functions of humanitarian organizations. Staff regularly
label: BODY

text: need to decide whether and how to share their organization’s data, even if their role is not primarily
label: BODY

text: focused on data or information management. Beyond individual organizations, the interest in the
label: BODY

text: sharing and use of data generated in humanitarian action has also grown. In response to this interest, the
label: BODY

text: humanitarian sector has seen a surge in data generation and sharing in recent years.
label: BODY

text: “Accurate data is the lifeblood of good policy and decision-making.
label: BODY

text: Obtaining it, and sharing it across hundreds of organizations, in the middle
label: BODY

text: of a humanitarian emergency, is complicated and time-consuming — but it is
label: BODY

text: absolutely crucial. ”
label: BODY

text: - United Nations Secretary-General António Guterres at the opening of the OCHA Centre for
label: BODY

text: Humanitarian Data in The Hague in December 2017
label: BODY

text: Open sharing of timely and accurate data is essential to effective and efficient humanitarian response and
label: BODY

text: should remain a key objective for the sector. For example, the COVID-19 epidemiological data1 compiled
label: BODY

text: and shared daily by the Johns Hopkins University Center for Systems Science and Engineering has been
label: BODY

text: 1   Access the Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19) Cases Data on HDX.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 2   “From August 2016 through August 2020 (the period for which the data is available), growth in monthly users from HRP+ countries was 943%
label: BODY

text: compared to 566% across all countries.” From the HDX Case Study, September 2020.
label: BODY

text: 3   These include, for example, the IASC Sub-Group on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action, the Protection Information Management
label: BODY

text: initiative, and the Responsible Data for Children initiative, among others.
label: BODY

text: 4   For a better understanding of the challenge facing humanitarian organizations when sharing data specifically in protracted humanitarian crises,
label: BODY

text: see ALNAP, Data Collection, Analysis and Use in Protracted Humanitarian Crises, June 2020.
label: BODY

text: 5   Learn more about the Centre’s risk mitigation process for microdata, ‘Statistical Disclosure Control’ or SDC in the Learning Path on the topic.
label: BODY

text: integrated in a number of dashboards and situation reports for decision-makers across the humanitarian
label: BODY

text: sector since the outset of the pandemic. By December 2020, this dataset had been downloaded more than
label: BODY

text: 320,000 times from the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) since it was first published on the platform in
label: BODY

text: January that year. The utility of open data to humanitarian practitioners is further underlined by the fact
label: BODY

text: that usage of HDX in countries with a Humanitarian Response Plan (HRP) in place has grown much faster
label: BODY

text: than usage in other locations.2
label: BODY

text: How humanitarian organizations approach data sharing directly relates to trust and cooperation in the
label: BODY

text: sector. Maintaining trust within the data ecosystem is critical to the sustainability of data sharing and
label: BODY

text: relates to issues such as the quality of the data, the level to which the data will be secured after sharing
label: BODY

text: and the responsible use of data by the recipient. Because data in the humanitarian sector often relates to
label: BODY

text: the most at-risk populations, managing and sharing it warrants caution.
label: BODY

text: Many humanitarian organizations have developed or updated their guidance, governance and practices
label: BODY

text: to support different aspects of data responsibility: the safe, ethical and effective management of data. The
label: BODY

text: sector has also seen an increasing number of collaborative efforts to improve data responsibility beyond
label: BODY

text: individual organizations.3 Still, as the humanitarian system learns more about the risks associated with
label: BODY

text: data sharing, organizations face more complex challenges in sharing this data responsibly.4
label: BODY

text: This guidance note aims to support decision-making around the sharing of non-personal data in
label: BODY

text: humanitarian settings. It explains data sensitivity, provides common examples of sensitive non-personal
label: BODY

text: data, and explains an approach to information and data sensitivity classification in humanitarian settings.
label: BODY

text: It also offers a framework that organizations can use to weigh four factors that help determine whether
label: BODY

text: data can be shared and explains common approaches for doing so responsibly.
label: BODY

text: Options for Data Sharing on the Humanitarian Data Exchange
label: BODY

text: When the Humanitarian Data Exchange (HDX) was launched in 2014, it held close to 900 datasets, shared
label: BODY

text: by a handful of ‘early adopter’ organizations. By the end of 2020, that number had grown to over 18,000
label: BODY

text: datasets. Only approved organizations are able to share data on the platform. They can make data
label: BODY

text: available publicly to anyone who visits the site or privately to only the members of their organizations.
label: BODY

text: In 2017, the HDX team added another option for data sharing: HDX Connect. This feature enables
label: BODY

text: organizations to only publish the metadata, with the underlying data available upon request. If access is
label: BODY

text: granted, the data is shared bilaterally without passing through the HDX platform. For example, Ground
label: BODY

text: Truth Solutions use HDX Connect to provide access to COVID-19 Community Perceptions Data collected in
label: BODY

text: Iraq.
label: BODY

text: As part of its quality assurance process, the HDX team also runs a disclosure risk assessment on any
label: BODY

text: resource added to the platform that contains microdata. The HDX team does this because it may be
label: BODY

text: possible to re-identify individuals or expose confidential information even after direct identifiers have been
label: BODY

text: removed from microdata.5
label: BODY

text: Some organizations on HDX have become more oriented towards controlled access to their data, either
label: BODY

text: due to the sensitive nature of the data, increased pressure to track and report on how the data is used,
label: BODY

text: or resource constraints related to operational sustainability. HDX will always support different ways of
label: BODY

text: sharing data — however, open access remains the best option for the majority of data that is generated for
label: BODY

text: humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA
label: HH1

text: DECEMBER 2020
label: BODY

text: 6   Personal data should not be shared openly, and management of personal data should always comply with national and regional data protection laws, or with
label: BODY

text: internal data protection policies in the case of organizations covered by privileges and immunities.
label: BODY

text: 7    UNOCHA (2019), Working Draft Data Responsibility Guidelines.
label: BODY

text: UNDERSTANDING DATA SENSITIVITY
label: HH1

text: Humanitarian organizations widely recognize the sensitivity of personal data6: its exposure has a high
label: BODY

text: likelihood of causing harm. This understanding does not yet widely exist for non-personal data, which
label: BODY

text: typically covers the following three categories in humanitarian settings:
label: BODY

text: 1.	Data about the context in which a response is taking place (e.g. legal frameworks, political, social
label: BODY

text: and economic conditions, infrastructure, etc.) and the humanitarian situation (e.g security incidents,
label: BODY

text: protection risks, drivers of the situation or crisis).
label: BODY

text: 2.	Data about the people affected by the situation and their needs, the threats and vulnerabilities they
label: BODY

text: face, and their capacities.
label: BODY

text: 3.	Data about humanitarian response actors and their activities (e.g. as reported in  3W/4W/5W).
label: BODY

text: The majority of this data is safe to share openly. However, non-personal data can also be sensitive.
label: BODY

text: Examples of sensitive non-personal data include data on groups experiencing gender-based violence or the
label: BODY

text: location of ethnic minorities in conflict settings. Such data is considered sensitive because it enables the
label: BODY

text: identification of groups of individuals by demographically defining factors, such as ethnicity, gender, age,
label: BODY

text: occupation, religion or location of origin. Non-personal data can also create risk in other ways, for example
label: BODY

text: by exposing the location of medical facilities in areas where they are prone to attack. As the awareness of
label: BODY

text: the risk associated with sharing such data continues to grow, some organizations are turning from a focus
label: BODY

text: on open data to more controlled sharing.
label: BODY

text: Many organizations have information and data sensitivity classifications (see figure 1 below)  that define
label: BODY

text: which data falls into which category of sensitivity in order to facilitate responsible data management. These
label: BODY

text: classifications may also be developed as a collective exercise to help organizations align around what
label: BODY

text: constitutes sensitive data in their context and identify the appropriate disclosure or dissemination methods
label: BODY

text: for different data types depending on their sensitivity.
label: BODY

text: Information and Data Sensitivity Classification7
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Low or No
label: BODY

text: Information or data that, if disclosed or accessed
label: BODY

text: without proper authorization, are unlikely to
label: BODY

text: cause any harm or negative impacts to affected
label: BODY

text: people and/or humanitarian actors.
label: BODY

text: Public
label: BODY

text: Moderate
label: BODY

text: Information or data that, if disclosed or accessed
label: BODY

text: without proper authorization, are likely to cause
label: BODY

text: minor harm or negative impacts and/or be disad-
label: BODY

text: vantageous for affected people and/or humani-
label: BODY

text: tarian actors.
label: BODY

text: Restricted
label: BODY

text: High
label: BODY

text: Information or data that, if disclosed or accessed
label: BODY

text: without proper authorization, are likely to cause
label: BODY

text: serious harm or negative impacts to affected peo-
label: BODY

text: ple and/or humanitarian actors and/or damage to
label: BODY

text: a response.
label: BODY

text: Confidential
label: BODY

label: BODY

text: Information or data that, if disclosed or accessed
label: BODY

text: without proper authorization, are likely to cause
label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: 8    See the Guidance Note on Data Impact Assessments.
label: BODY

text: 9    For data management in the humanitarian sector, risk can be defined as the likelihood and impact of harm resulting from data management.
label: BODY

text: 10  The World Economic Forum, together with Washington University Centre for Information Assurance and Cybersecurity, the Sustainable
label: BODY

text: Development Solutions Network TReNDS and the NYU GovLab, have begun building a repository of data sharing agreements to support the
label: BODY

text: professionalization of this practice through their Contracts for Data Collaboration (C4DC) project.
label: BODY

text: 11   The licenses recommended for data sharing via HDX are listed here: https://data.humdata.org/about/license.
label: BODY

text: 12  For more information about data incident management in humanitarian response, see our Guidance Note on Data Incident Management.
label: BODY

text: Organizational policies and collective governance instruments such as Information Sharing Protocols
label: BODY

text: (ISPs) often include a sensitivity classification and should be the primary points of reference for
label: BODY

text: determining how to manage sensitive data. However, these documents tend to leave room for discretion
label: BODY

text: regarding whether and how to share. This means data sharing can be influenced by personal preferences
label: BODY

text: and skills and may vary across organizations. By taking a more consistent approach to data sharing and
label: BODY

text: ensuring adequate safeguards for sensitive data, organizations can build trust and contribute to more
label: BODY

text: efficient and effective humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: FOUR FACTORS FOR DETERMINING WHETHER TO SHARE NON-PERSONAL DATA
label: HH1

text: There are four factors humanitarian organizations should take into account when deciding whether to
label: BODY

text: share non-personal data.
label: BODY

text: 1.	  What is the utility of the data for other stakeholders?
label: HH1

text: The utility of data depends on the level of detail, the number of people or the geographical area
label: BODY

text: covered, its timeliness, and its relevance to analysis and decision-making in humanitarian response.
label: BODY

text: Conduct a Data Impact Assessment (DIA) to help determine the utility of specific data.8
label: BODY

text: 2.	   How sensitive is the data?
label: HH1

text: The sensitivity of data is based on the risk associated with its exposure in a particular context.9 In
label: BODY

text: some response contexts, organizations, clusters/sectors, and system-wide coordination structures
label: BODY

text: also have established data and information sensitivity classifications (see above) that can inform this
label: BODY

text: determination. Conducting a DIA can also help determine the sensitivity of data. For survey results
label: BODY

text: and other forms of microdata, sensitivity is closely linked to the risk of re-identification, which can
label: BODY

text: be determined by applying a disclosure risk assessment.
label: BODY

text: 3.	 What human and technical capacity do the organizations sharing and using the data have?
label: HH1

text: Both the organization sharing data and the organization(s) receiving and using the data should
label: BODY

text: have sufficient human and technical capacity for responsible data management. This includes staff
label: BODY

text: availability, data literacy, technical infrastructure and related resources. In environments with low
label: BODY

text: connectivity, bandwidth-heavy data sharing methods may not be appropriate. For contexts with
label: BODY

text: known security risks, data should typically be shared through more limited approaches.
label: BODY

text: 4.	 Which governance instruments apply?
label: HH1

text: Common data governance instruments include ISPs, data sharing agreements for bilateral data
label: BODY

text: sharing and licenses or terms of use for public data sharing.11 These instruments should inform how
label: BODY

text: data is shared in a safe, ethical and effective manner. In some situations, governance will need to
label: BODY

text: be developed for the selected data sharing approach. Governance instruments can address a range
label: BODY

text: of topics and special provisions, but should always include the following elements: (a) the purpose
label: BODY

text: and scope of sharing; (b) any limitations to how data should be managed after sharing; (c) roles and
label: BODY

text: responsibilities throughout the sharing process; and (d) procedures for data incident management.12
label: BODY

text: THE CENTRE FOR HUMANITARIAN DATA

label: BODY

label: BODY

label: BODY

text: IDENTIFY AND COMPARE APPROACHES
label: HH1

text: Organizations should determine the best approach to data sharing based on the four factors above. These
label: BODY

text: approaches range from open sharing to maximize the benefit of data, to more limited approaches such
label: BODY

text: as bilateral data sharing or only sharing data insights. The table below contains an overview of different
label: BODY

text: approaches to data sharing and offers examples of some commonly used tools and platforms.
label: BODY

text: Approaches to
label: HH1

text: Sharing
label: BODY

text: Approaches, Tools and Platforms for Data Sharing in Humanitarian Response 13
label: BODY

text: Open Access
label: BODY

text: Sharing data
label: BODY

text: publicly is the most
label: BODY

text: open approach to
label: BODY

text: sharing, allowing
label: BODY

text: unmediated access
label: BODY

text: to anyone.
label: BODY

text: Limited Access
label: BODY

text: Limiting access to
label: BODY

text: data still allows
label: BODY

text: select partners to
label: BODY

text: use the data as long
label: BODY

text: as they meet certain
label: BODY

text: requirements.
label: BODY

text: Bilateral Sharing
label: BODY

text: Bilateral sharing is
label: BODY

text: the most limited
label: BODY

text: way in which data
label: BODY

text: can be shared,
label: BODY

text: directly with one
label: BODY

text: partner.
label: BODY

text: No Data Sharing
label: BODY

text: Data that should
label: BODY

text: not be shared at all
label: BODY

text: can still offer value
label: BODY

text: to partners, if they
label: BODY

text: are allowed to query
label: BODY

text: the data remotely
label: BODY

text: or benefit from it
label: BODY

text: indirectly.
label: BODY

text: In comparing these different approaches, always consider the most open approach first and work down
label: BODY

text: to more limited approaches as necessary. Different data types will require different ways of sharing. For
label: BODY

text: example, large datafiles will require specialized infrastructure and Application Programming Interfaces
label: BODY

text: (APIs) are suitable for data that is published in the same format on a regular basis. Because technologies
label: BODY

text: for data sharing continue to evolve, organizations should regularly revisit and compare available data
label: BODY

text: sharing approaches.
label: BODY

text: COLLABORATORS: JOINT IDP PROFILING SERVICE (JIPS).
label: BODY

text: The Centre for Humanitarian Data ('the Center'), together with key partners, is publishing a series of eight
label: BODY

text: guidance notes on Data Responsibility in Humanitarian Action over the course of 2019 and 2020. The Guidance
label: BODY

text: Note series follows the publication of the OCHA Data Responsibility Guidelines in March 2019. Through
label: BODY

text: the series, the Centre aims to provide additional guidance on specific issues, processes and tools for data
label: BODY

text: responsibility in practice. This series is made possible with the generous support of the Directorate-General for
label: BODY

text: European Civil Protection and Humanitarian Aid Operations (DG ECHO).
label: BODY

text: Unlocking Value from Data Without Sharing It: The Querying Approach
label: BODY

text: A relatively new approach to utilizing data without transferring the data itself is ‘querying’. Querying
label: BODY

text: allows third parties to formulate specific questions to be asked of the data without accessing it directly.
label: BODY

text: The resulting insights can then be checked for sensitivity and any other issues by the holder of the data.
label: BODY

text: This approach avoids transfers of data which can cause legal and ethical concerns, while still allowing for
label: BODY

text: valuable insights to be used for public good.
label: BODY

text: In implementing a querying approach, it is critical to establish governance in the form of instructions and
label: BODY

text: boundaries regarding the queries that may be sent, in order to prevent retrieval of sensitive information by
label: BODY

text: posing a combination of questions.21 Vetting users as well as their questions should always be a key step in
label: BODY

text: the process around this type of approach.
label: BODY

text: Commercial solutions to set up querying approaches include Aircloak Insights, which acts as a ‘proxy
label: BODY

text: between analysts and the sensitive data they need to work with.’ Another querying tool is the Open
label: BODY

text: Algorithms (OPAL) platform. This tool was specifically developed for the humanitarian and development
label: BODY

text: sectors and is currently being piloted in Colombia.
label: BODY

text: Data Sharing Methods at the Joint IDP Profiling Service
label: HH1

text: In 2019, the Joint IDP Profiling Service (JIPS) was awarded a grant by the UNHCR Innovation Fund to
label: BODY

text: research advanced data science methods for data anonymization. JIPS studied methods such as Multi-
label: BODY

text: Party Computation and Homomorphic Encryption and worked with technical experts at the Johns Hopkins
label: BODY

text: University Applied Physics Laboratory, Flowminder and the Government of Colombia National Statistics
label: BODY

text: Office.
label: BODY

text: In close collaboration with Flowminder and building on their Flowkit, JIPS developed a prototype
label: BODY

text: querying approach to enable humanitarian and development actors to safely access and query sensitive
label: BODY

text: individual-level data without needing to share it. The team developed a technical workflow to demonstrate
label: BODY

text: the viability of this approach with one single data provider and mapped the problems and limitations in
label: BODY

text: case of multiple data providers.
label: BODY

text: Organizations are encouraged to share their experience in promoting responsible data sharing with the
label: BODY

text: Centre for Humanitarian Data via centrehumdata@un.org.
label: BODY
